channel.title: Headset microphone doesn't work
channel.description:
As the title says, my headset's microphone doesn't work. It's not damaged or anything, and I've went into the sound area, and made sure it was enabled. Can anyone find a fix for my microphone? It's a Sades SA-708 Thanks :D
[IMG]http://i61.tinypic.com/ofx0sx.png[/img]

item.title: Headset microphone doesn't work
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Ok cool, thanks sk8r
I’ll edit this post with updates on how it goes etc.

Read full topic

item.title: Headset microphone doesn't work
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Lil_Smok3r:

ehmm check the attached image.

Well “Unsupported Standard Game Port” is probably your headphones (Assuming they were plugged in during the screenie).

The other 2… Yeah that doesn’t tell me anything.
Check on AMD’s site for drivers, and I can’t say much for the High Definition Audio Device because that’s a broad name from hell.
You could look into Realteks Audio drivers because they might be the right ones.

Read full topic

item.title: Headset microphone doesn't work
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

[quote=“Lil_Smok3r, post:9, topic:545500”][quote author=Justin Bieber link=topic=664383.msg4441524#msg4441524 date=1406804257]
USB or audio jack?
[/quote]
Audio jack

Ripped this from another website:

[quote]Okay. Open the Device Manager (type devmgmt.msc into the search box) and expand Sound…Controllers. If you do not see “Sigmatel” then you are using the native Windows audio driver which does not recognize external mics. If that is the case then install the Sigmatel audio driver. There was not one for 7 so you have to use the Vista version.

Download Sigmatel R171788 and extract the files (unzip or unpack and make a note of the name of the folder that is created) but cancel the installation process. Go to the folder on the hard drive to which you unpacked the driver files
c:\Dell\Drivers\Rxxxxxx

Find the setup.exe file and right click on it. Select the Properties. Find the compatibility tab and select Vista.

After the driver is installed, go to the Control Panel and click on Sigmatel. Check the option to allow popups if it is not already checked. When you plug in your mic you should get a popup configuration window. Select mic, not line-in. (If you don’t check “allow popups” then the jack configuration defaults to either mic or line-in. If it is line-in then the mic won’t have enough boost to work.)

Note that the Vista version is most compatible with 7, but you ought to be able to use the same method above to install the XP version, Sigmatel R171789. That driver has stereo mix, which the Vista version lacks.[/quote]
Source
Note: This was for a dell.

Would that driver work for my headset?

EDIT: I tried the compatability thing, and now a message saying “Please connect the Sades SA-708 Gaming Headset” even though it’s already plugged in :mad:[/quote]
Have you tried turning it off and on again?

Read full topic

item.title: Headset microphone doesn't work
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

Justin Bieber:

USB or audio jack?

Audio jack

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:8, topic:545500”]Ripped this from another website:

[quote]Okay. Open the Device Manager (type devmgmt.msc into the search box) and expand Sound…Controllers. If you do not see “Sigmatel” then you are using the native Windows audio driver which does not recognize external mics. If that is the case then install the Sigmatel audio driver. There was not one for 7 so you have to use the Vista version.

Download Sigmatel R171788 and extract the files (unzip or unpack and make a note of the name of the folder that is created) but cancel the installation process. Go to the folder on the hard drive to which you unpacked the driver files
c:\Dell\Drivers\Rxxxxxx

Find the setup.exe file and right click on it. Select the Properties. Find the compatibility tab and select Vista.

After the driver is installed, go to the Control Panel and click on Sigmatel. Check the option to allow popups if it is not already checked. When you plug in your mic you should get a popup configuration window. Select mic, not line-in. (If you don’t check “allow popups” then the jack configuration defaults to either mic or line-in. If it is line-in then the mic won’t have enough boost to work.)

Note that the Vista version is most compatible with 7, but you ought to be able to use the same method above to install the XP version, Sigmatel R171789. That driver has stereo mix, which the Vista version lacks.[/quote]
Source
Note: This was for a dell.[/quote]
Would that driver work for my headset?

EDIT: I tried the compatability thing, and now a message saying “Please connect the Sades SA-708 Gaming Headset” even though it’s already plugged in :mad:

Read full topic

item.title: Headset microphone doesn't work
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Ripped this from another website:

Okay. Open the Device Manager (type devmgmt.msc into the search box) and expand Sound...Controllers. If you do not see "Sigmatel" then you are using the native Windows audio driver which does not recognize external mics. If that is the case then install the Sigmatel audio driver. There was not one for 7 so you have to use the Vista version.

Download Sigmatel R171788 and extract the files (unzip or unpack and make a note of the name of the folder that is created) but cancel the installation process. Go to the folder on the hard drive to which you unpacked the driver files
c:\Dell\Drivers\Rxxxxxx

Find the setup.exe file and right click on it. Select the Properties. Find the compatibility tab and select Vista.

After the driver is installed, go to the Control Panel and click on Sigmatel. Check the option to allow popups if it is not already checked. When you plug in your mic you should get a popup configuration window. Select mic, not line-in. (If you don’t check “allow popups” then the jack configuration defaults to either mic or line-in. If it is line-in then the mic won’t have enough boost to work.)

Note that the Vista version is most compatible with 7, but you ought to be able to use the same method above to install the XP version, Sigmatel R171789. That driver has stereo mix, which the Vista version lacks.


Source
Note: This was for a dell.

Read full topic
